blocks.name: gcdi
blocks.content: Calculate a GCD via Euclid's algorithm. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 19-Feb-2014.)

thm gcdi(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4) {
  |- wceq(co(c0, cgcd, c1), c2)
  -| wcel(c3, cn0)
  -| wcel(c4, cn0)
  -| wcel(c1, cn0)
  -| wceq(co(c1, cgcd, c4), c2)
  -| wceq(co(co(c3, cmul, c1), caddc, c4), c0)
} = {
  eqtr3i(co(c0, cgcd, c1), c2, co(c1, cgcd, c4))
  3eqtr4i(co(c1, cgcd, c4), co(c0, cgcd, c1), co(c1, cgcd, co(c4, caddc, co(c3, cmul, c1))), co(c1, cgcd, c0))
  oveq2i(c1, cgcd, co(c4, caddc, co(c3, cmul, c1)), c0)
  addcomli(c4, co(c3, cmul, c1), c0)
  nn0cni(co(c3, cmul, c1))
  nn0mulcli(c3, c1)
  nn0cni(c4)
  mp3an(wceq(co(c1, cgcd, c4), co(c1, cgcd, co(c4, caddc, co(c3, cmul, c1)))), wcel(c3, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c4, cz))
  nn0zi(c3)
  nn0zi(c4)
  gcdaddm(c3, c1, c4)
  mp2an(wceq(co(c0, cgcd, c1), co(c1, cgcd, c0)), wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz))
  nn0zi(c0)
  eqeltrri(c0, cn0, co(co(c3, cmul, c1), caddc, c4))
  numcl(c3, c1, c4)
  nn0zi(c1)
  gcdcom(c0, c1)
}

blocks.name: gcdmodi
blocks.content: Calculate a GCD via Euclid's algorithm. Theorem 5.6 in [ApostolNT] p. 109. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 19-Feb-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm gcdmodi(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  |- wceq(co(c0, cgcd, c1), c2)
  -| wcel(c0, cn0)
  -| wcel(c3, cn0)
  -| wcel(c1, cn)
  -| wceq(co(c0, cmo, c1), co(c3, cmo, c1))
  -| wceq(co(c1, cgcd, c3), c2)
} = {
  3eqtri(co(c0, cgcd, c1), c2, co(c3, cgcd, c1), co(c1, cgcd, c3))
  3eqtr3i(co(c0, cgcd, c1), co(c3, cgcd, c1), co(co(c0, cmo, c1), cgcd, c1), co(co(c3, cmo, c1), cgcd, c1))
  oveq1i(co(c0, cmo, c1), cgcd, c1, co(c3, cmo, c1))
  mp2an(wceq(co(co(c0, cmo, c1), cgcd, c1), co(c0, cgcd, c1)), wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn))
  nn0zi(c0)
  modgcd(c0, c1)
  mp2an(wceq(co(co(c3, cmo, c1), cgcd, c1), co(c3, cgcd, c1)), wcel(c3, cz), wcel(c1, cn))
  modgcd(c3, c1)
  mp2an(wceq(co(c3, cgcd, c1), co(c1, cgcd, c3)), wcel(c3, cz), wcel(c1, cz))
  nn0zi(c3)
  nnzi(c1)
  gcdcom(c3, c1)
}

thm gcdmodi(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  ⊢ (c0[gcd]c1)= c2
  ⊣ c0 ∈ ℕ0
  ⊣ c3 ∈ ℕ0
  ⊣ c1 ∈ ℕ
  ⊣ (c0[mod]c1)=(c3[mod]c1)
  ⊣ (c1[gcd]c3)= c2
} = {
  3eqtri((c0[gcd]c1), c2, (c3[gcd]c1), (c1[gcd]c3))
  3eqtr3i((c0[gcd]c1), (c3[gcd]c1), ((c0[mod]c1)[gcd]c1), ((c3[mod]c1)[gcd]c1))
  oveq1i((c0[mod]c1), cgcd, c1, (c3[mod]c1))
  mp2an(((c0[mod]c1)[gcd]c1)=(c0[gcd]c1), c0 ∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℕ)
  nn0zi(c0)
  modgcd(c0, c1)
  mp2an(((c3[mod]c1)[gcd]c1)=(c3[gcd]c1), c3 ∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℕ)
  modgcd(c3, c1)
  mp2an((c3[gcd]c1)=(c1[gcd]c3), c3 ∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℤ)
  nn0zi(c3)
  nnzi(c1)
  gcdcom(c3, c1)
}

  mp2an(wceq(co(nat2, cexp, co(c0, caddc, nat1)), co(co(nat2, cexp, c0), cmul, nat2)), wcel(nat2, cc), wcel(c0, cn0))
  expp1(nat2, c0)
  mulcomi(co(nat2, cexp, c0), nat2)

  mp2an(wceq(co(nat2, cexp, co(co(c0, caddc, nat1), caddc, nat1)), co(co(nat2, cexp, co(c0, caddc, nat1)), cmul, nat2)), wcel(nat2, cc), wcel(co(c0, caddc, nat1), cn0))
  2cn()

  peano2nn0(c0)
  expp1(nat2, co(c0, caddc, nat1))
  addid1i(co(nat4, cmul, co(nat2, cexp, c0)))
  nn0cni(co(nat4, cmul, co(nat2, cexp, c0)))

blocks.name: karatsuba
blocks.content: The Karatsuba multiplication algorithm. If ` X ` and ` Y ` are decomposed into two groups of digits of length ` M ` (only the lower group is known to be this size but the algorithm is most efficient when the partition is chosen near the middle of the digit string), then ` X Y ` can be written in three groups of digits, where each group needs only one multiplication. Thus, we can halve both inputs with only three multiplications on the smaller operands, yielding an asymptotic improvement of n^(log_2 3) instead of n^2 for the "naive" algorithm ~ decmul1c . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 16-Jul-2015.) (Revised by AV, 9-Sep-2021.)
